data.title: The “Sheep Pig”
data.meta_description: MooShu's antics have been on a low key this past week, as he's more interested in eating, foraging and making his nest for the winter. So, I thought I would share some interesting tidbits on a rare pig breed I came across. The Mangalica (or Mangalitsa in the U.S. and Mangalitza in Hungary) is often referred to…
data.text:
MooShu’s antics have been on a low key this past week, as he’s more interested in eating, foraging and making his nest for the winter. So, I thought I would share some interesting tidbits on a rare pig breed I came across.

The Mangalica (or Mangalitsa in the U.S. and Mangalitza in Hungary) is often referred to as the “sheep pig” due to their wooly coat. Originating, and mainly found in Hungary, it is a domestic pig bred for meat production.

Lincolnshire Curly-Coated Pig

The only other known pig that had similar hair was the Lincolnshire Curly-coated Pig from England, which is now extinct.

There are three separate breeds of Mangalitsa currently in existence: Blonde, Swallow-bellied, and Red.

Blonde Mangalica

The Blonde is the only pure-bred remaining in this line of pigs, as the other two breeds were a result of cross breeding.

Swallow-bellied Mangalica

The Swallow-Bellied was produced through breeding the Blonde with the now extinct Black Mangalica.

Red Mangalica with piglets

The Red is a result of cross breeding between the Blonde and the Szalonta Breed.

The other extinct pure-breds are the Wolf and Baris. (pictures unavailable)

Hungary is currently attempting to reconstruct these breeds from highly debated selective breeding techniques.
